packages.${system}.default = pkgs.writeShellScriptBin "search-bash-histories" ''
      # Â±•Ê≠¥„Åã„ÇâÈÅ∏Êäû„Åó„Å¶ÁµêÊûú„ÇíÂá∫ÂäõÔºà„Ç≠„É£„É≥„Çª„É´ÊôÇ„ÅØ‰Ωï„ÇÇÂá∫Âäõ„Åó„Å™„ÅÑÔºâ
      HISTTIMEFORMAT= history | 
          awk '{$1=""; print substr($0,2)}' |
          ${pkgs.fzf}/bin/fzf --height ''${FZF_TMUX_HEIGHT:-40%} $FZF_DEFAULT_OPTS -n2..,.. --tiebreak=index --bind=ctrl-r:toggle-sort $FZF_CTRL_R_OPTS --query="$READLINE_LINE" +m
    '';
input.new_string:
packages.${system}.default = pkgs.writeShellScriptBin "search-bash-histories" ''
      # Â±•Ê≠¥„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„Åã„ÇâÁõ¥Êé•Ë™≠„ÅøËæº„ÇÄ
      if [ -f ~/.bash_history ]; then
        tac ~/.bash_history | 
        awk '!seen[$0]++' | 
        ${pkgs.fzf}/bin/fzf --height ''${FZF_TMUX_HEIGHT:-40%} $FZF_DEFAULT_OPTS -n2..,.. --tiebreak=index --bind=ctrl-r:toggle-sort $FZF_CTRL_R_OPTS --query="$READLINE_LINE" +m
      else
        echo "No bash history file found" >&2
        exit 1
      fi
    '';

# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"
```

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

ARGUMENTS: 

after remove result bin
I'll commit only the files I edited, excluding the result and bin directories.

    17‚Üí  „Å™„Åó

    20‚Üí  # Êé®Â•®: tmux-shell.shÁµåÁî±„ÅßËµ∑ÂãïÔºàbashrc„ÇÇË™≠„ÅøËæº„Åæ„Çå„ÇãÔºâ
    21‚Üí  ./tmux-shell.sh

    23‚Üí  # Áõ¥Êé•ÂÆüË°åÔºàÂÆüË°åÊ®©Èôê„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„ÄÅÈùûÊé®Â•®Ôºâ
    24‚Üí  ./main.sh

    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí
    33‚Üí„Ç≠„Éº„Éê„Ç§„É≥„Éâ:
    34‚Üí  Ctrl-b + 0/1      windowÂàá„ÇäÊõø„Åà
    35‚Üí  Ctrl-b + S        „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥Âàá„ÇäÊõø„Åà
    36‚Üí  Ctrl-b + C        Êñ∞Ë¶è„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥‰ΩúÊàê
    37‚Üí  Ctrl-b + v        „Ç≥„Éî„Éº„É¢„Éº„Éâ
    38‚Üí  Ctrl-b + h/j/k/l  „Éö„Ç§„É≥ÁßªÂãï

    40‚Üí  Ctrl-b + c        flake„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ÈÅ∏Êäû„Åó„Å¶Êñ∞Ë¶èwindow‰ΩúÊàê
    41‚ÜíEOF

    43‚Üífi
    44‚Üí
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí# „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥ÂêçÔºà„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„Éô„Éº„ÇπÔºâ
    47‚ÜíSESSION_NAME="$(basename $(pwd))"
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí# „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥ÂèÇÂä†„Åæ„Åü„ÅØ‰ΩúÊàê
    50‚Üíif tmux has-session -t $SESSION_NAME 2>/dev/null; then
    51‚Üí    echo "Attaching to existing session: $SESSION_NAME"

    54‚Üíelse

    57‚Üífi
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí# tmuxË®≠ÂÆö
    60‚Üí# ====================
    61‚Üí# ÂÖ±ÈÄöÈñ¢Êï∞ÂÆöÁæ©
    62‚Üí# ====================
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí# 2ÂàÜÂâ≤‰ΩúÊàêÔºà50%-50%Ôºâ
    65‚Üícreate_2_split() {
    66‚Üí    local target="$1"
    67‚Üí    tmux split-window -h -t "$target" -p 50
    68‚Üí}
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí# ====================
    71‚Üí# tmuxÂü∫Êú¨Ë®≠ÂÆö
    72‚Üí# ====================
    73‚Üítmux set -g mode-keys vi
    74‚Üítmux set -g status-keys vi
    75‚Üítmux setw -g monitor-activity on
    76‚Üí
    77‚Üí# ====================
    78‚Üí# „Ç´„É©„Éº„ÉÜ„Éº„ÉûË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Éü„Éã„Éû„É´Êöó„ÇÅÔºâ
    79‚Üí# ====================
    80‚Üí# Âü∫Êú¨„Ç´„É©„ÉºÂÆöÁæ©
    81‚ÜíBG_BASE="colour236"      # „Éô„Éº„ÇπËÉåÊôØÔºàÊøÉ„ÅÑ„Ç∞„É¨„ÉºÔºâ
    82‚ÜíBG_ACTIVE="colour238"    # „Ç¢„ÇØ„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉñËÉåÊôØÔºàÂ∞ë„ÅóÊòé„Çã„ÇÅÔºâ
    83‚ÜíFG_DIM="colour242"       # ËñÑÊöó„ÅÑÊñáÂ≠ó
    84‚ÜíFG_NORMAL="colour245"    # ÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊñáÂ≠ó
    85‚ÜíFG_BRIGHT="colour250"    # Êòé„Çã„ÅÑÊñáÂ≠ó
    86‚ÜíFG_ALERT="colour214"     # „Ç¢„É©„Éº„ÉàÔºàÊéß„Åà„ÇÅ„Å™„Ç™„É¨„É≥„Ç∏Ôºâ
    87‚Üí
    88‚Üí# „Éö„Ç§„É≥„Çπ„Çø„Ç§„É´
    89‚Üítmux set -g window-style "fg=$FG_NORMAL"
    90‚Üítmux set -g window-active-style "fg=colour255"
    91‚Üí
    92‚Üí# „Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„Çπ„Éê„Éº
    93‚Üítmux set-option -g status-style "bg=$BG_BASE,fg=$FG_NORMAL"
    94‚Üítmux set-option -g window-status-current-style "bg=$BG_ACTIVE,fg=$FG_BRIGHT"
    95‚Üítmux set-option -g window-status-style "bg=$BG_BASE,fg=$FG_DIM"
    96‚Üítmux set-option -g window-status-activity-style "bg=$BG_BASE,fg=$FG_ALERT"
    97‚Üítmux set-option -g window-status-format " #I:#W "
    98‚Üítmux set-option -g window-status-current-format " #I:#W* "
    99‚Üí
   100‚Üí# window‰ΩúÊàêÈñ¢Êï∞
   101‚Üícreate_window() {
   102‚Üí    local idx=$1
   103‚Üí    local name=$2
   104‚Üí    local cmd1="${3:-}"
   105‚Üí    local cmd2="${4:-}"
   106‚Üí    
   107‚Üí    if [ $idx -eq 0 ]; then
   108‚Üí        # window 0„ÅÆÁâπÂà•Âá¶ÁêÜ
   109‚Üí        tmux rename-window -t "$SESSION_NAME:$idx" "$name"
   110‚Üí        create_2_split "$SESSION_NAME:$idx"
   111‚Üí        # „Ç≥„Éû„É≥„ÉâÂÆüË°å
   112‚Üí        [ -n "$cmd1" ] && tmux send-keys -t "$SESSION_NAME:$idx.0" "$cmd1" Enter
   113‚Üí        [ -n "$cmd2" ] && tmux send-keys -t "$SESSION_NAME:$idx.1" "$cmd2" Enter
   114‚Üí    else
   115‚Üí        # window 1‰ª•Èôç„ÅØÂçò„Å´new-window„Åô„Çã„Å†„ÅëÔºàhooks„Åå4ÂàÜÂâ≤„ÇíÂá¶ÁêÜÔºâ
   116‚Üí        tmux new-window -t "$SESSION_NAME" -n "$name"
   117‚Üí    fi
   118‚Üí}
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí# hookË®≠ÂÆö
   121‚Üísetup_hooks() {
   122‚Üí    # „Éö„Ç§„É≥ÁµÇ‰∫ÜÊôÇ„ÅÆÂá¶ÁêÜ
   123‚Üí    tmux set-hook -g pane-exited \
   124‚Üí        "run-shell 'idx=#{window_index}; \
   125‚Üí        if [ \$idx -eq 0 ]; then \
   126‚Üí            # window0„ÅØ2ÂàÜÂâ≤Á∂≠ÊåÅ
   127‚Üí            panes=\$(tmux list-panes -t #{session_name}:0 2>/dev/null | wc -l); \
   128‚Üí            [ \$panes -eq 1 ] && tmux split-window -h -t #{session_name}:0 -p 50; \
   129‚Üí        elif [ \$idx -ne 0 ]; then \
   130‚Üí            # window1‰ª•Èôç„ÅØ4ÂàÜÂâ≤Á∂≠ÊåÅÔºàÂùáÁ≠â„É¨„Ç§„Ç¢„Ç¶„Éà‰ΩøÁî®Ôºâ
   131‚Üí            panes=\$(tmux list-panes -t #{session_name}:#{window_index} 2>/dev/null | wc -l); \
   132‚Üí            if [ \$panes -lt 4 ] && [ \$panes -gt 0 ]; then \
   133‚Üí                # ÁèæÂú®„ÅÆwindow„ÅÆ„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„ÇíÂèñÂæó

   135‚Üí                # ‰∏çË∂≥ÂàÜ„ÅÆ„Éö„Ç§„É≥„ÇíËøΩÂä†ÔºàÂêå„Åò„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„ÅßÔºâ

#!/bin/bash

# tmuxÁµ±Âêà„Çπ„ÇØ„É™„Éó„Éà (main.sh)

# „Éò„É´„ÉóË°®Á§∫
if [[ "$1" == "--help" ]] || [[ "$1" == "-h" ]]; then
    cat << EOF
Usage: 
  ./tmux-shell.sh                          # Êé®Â•®: tmux-shell.shÁµåÁî±„ÅßËµ∑Âãï
  ./main.sh [options]                      # Áõ¥Êé•ÂÆüË°åÔºàÈùûÊé®Â•®Ôºâ
  nix develop -c bash main.sh [options]    # nix developÂÜÖ„ÅßÂÆüË°å
  nix run .#tmux-session [options]         # flake„Ç¢„Éó„É™„Å®„Åó„Å¶ÂÆüË°å

tmux Ê∞¥Âπ≥2ÂàÜÂâ≤ÊßãÊàê„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥‰ΩúÊàê„Çπ„ÇØ„É™„Éó„Éà (NixÁâà)

Áí∞Â¢ÉÂ§âÊï∞:
  „Å™„Åó

ÂÆüË°å‰æã:
  # Êé®Â•®: tmux-shell.shÁµåÁî±„ÅßËµ∑ÂãïÔºàbashrc„ÇÇË™≠„ÅøËæº„Åæ„Çå„ÇãÔºâ
  ./tmux-shell.sh
  
  # Áõ¥Êé•ÂÆüË°åÔºàÂÆüË°åÊ®©Èôê„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„ÄÅÈùûÊé®Â•®Ôºâ
  ./main.sh
  
  # nix developÁí∞Â¢ÉÂÜÖ„ÅßÂÆüË°å
  nix develop -c bash main.sh
  
  # flake„Ç¢„Éó„É™„Å®„Åó„Å¶ÂÆüË°å
  nix run .#tmux-session


„Ç≠„Éº„Éê„Ç§„É≥„Éâ:
  Ctrl-b + 0/1      windowÂàá„ÇäÊõø„Åà
  Ctrl-b + S        „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥Âàá„ÇäÊõø„Åà
  Ctrl-b + C        Êñ∞Ë¶è„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥‰ΩúÊàê
  Ctrl-b + v        „Ç≥„Éî„Éº„É¢„Éº„Éâ
  Ctrl-b + h/j/k/l  „Éö„Ç§„É≥ÁßªÂãï
  Ctrl-b + b        fzf„Åß„Éö„Ç§„É≥„Ç∏„É£„É≥„Éó
  Ctrl-b + c        flake„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ÈÅ∏Êäû„Åó„Å¶Êñ∞Ë¶èwindow‰ΩúÊàê
EOF
    exit 0
fi


# „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥ÂêçÔºà„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„Éô„Éº„ÇπÔºâ
SESSION_NAME="$(basename $(pwd))"

# „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥ÂèÇÂä†„Åæ„Åü„ÅØ‰ΩúÊàê
if tmux has-session -t $SESSION_NAME 2>/dev/null; then
    echo "Attaching to existing session: $SESSION_NAME"
    tmux attach-session -t $SESSION_NAME
    exit 0
else
    echo "Creating new session: $SESSION_NAME"
    tmux new-session -d -s $SESSION_NAME
fi

# tmuxË®≠ÂÆö
# ====================
# ÂÖ±ÈÄöÈñ¢Êï∞ÂÆöÁæ©
# ====================

# 2ÂàÜÂâ≤‰ΩúÊàêÔºà50%-50%Ôºâ
create_2_split() {
    local target="$1"
    tmux split-window -h -t "$target" -p 50
}

# ====================
# tmuxÂü∫Êú¨Ë®≠ÂÆö
# ====================
tmux set -g mode-keys vi
tmux set -g status-keys vi
tmux setw -g monitor-activity on

# ====================
# „Ç´„É©„Éº„ÉÜ„Éº„ÉûË®≠ÂÆöÔºà„Éü„Éã„Éû„É´Êöó„ÇÅÔºâ
# ====================
# Âü∫Êú¨„Ç´„É©„ÉºÂÆöÁæ©
BG_BASE="colour236"      # „Éô„Éº„ÇπËÉåÊôØÔºàÊøÉ„ÅÑ„Ç∞„É¨„ÉºÔºâ
BG_ACTIVE="colour238"    # „Ç¢„ÇØ„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉñËÉåÊôØÔºàÂ∞ë„ÅóÊòé„Çã„ÇÅÔºâ
FG_DIM="colour242"       # ËñÑÊöó„ÅÑÊñáÂ≠ó
FG_NORMAL="colour245"    # ÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊñáÂ≠ó
FG_BRIGHT="colour250"    # Êòé„Çã„ÅÑÊñáÂ≠ó
FG_ALERT="colour214"     # „Ç¢„É©„Éº„ÉàÔºàÊéß„Åà„ÇÅ„Å™„Ç™„É¨„É≥„Ç∏Ôºâ

# „Éö„Ç§„É≥„Çπ„Çø„Ç§„É´
tmux set -g window-style "fg=$FG_NORMAL"
tmux set -g window-active-style "fg=colour255"

# „Çπ„ÉÜ„Éº„Çø„Çπ„Éê„Éº
tmux set-option -g status-style "bg=$BG_BASE,fg=$FG_NORMAL"
tmux set-option -g window-status-current-style "bg=$BG_ACTIVE,fg=$FG_BRIGHT"
tmux set-option -g window-status-style "bg=$BG_BASE,fg=$FG_DIM"
tmux set-option -g window-status-activity-style "bg=$BG_BASE,fg=$FG_ALERT"
tmux set-option -g window-status-format " #I:#W "
tmux set-option -g window-status-current-format " #I:#W* "

# window‰ΩúÊàêÈñ¢Êï∞
create_window() {
    local idx=$1
    local name=$2
    local cmd1="${3:-}"
    local cmd2="${4:-}"
    
    if [ $idx -eq 0 ]; then
        # window 0„ÅÆÁâπÂà•Âá¶ÁêÜ
        tmux rename-window -t "$SESSION_NAME:$idx" "$name"
        create_2_split "$SESSION_NAME:$idx"
        # „Ç≥„Éû„É≥„ÉâÂÆüË°å
        [ -n "$cmd1" ] && tmux send-keys -t "$SESSION_NAME:$idx.0" "$cmd1" Enter
        [ -n "$cmd2" ] && tmux send-keys -t "$SESSION_NAME:$idx.1" "$cmd2" Enter
    else
        # window 1‰ª•Èôç„ÅØÂçò„Å´new-window„Åô„Çã„Å†„ÅëÔºàhooks„Åå4ÂàÜÂâ≤„ÇíÂá¶ÁêÜÔºâ
        tmux new-window -t "$SESSION_NAME" -n "$name"
    fi
}

# hookË®≠ÂÆö
setup_hooks() {
    # „Éö„Ç§„É≥ÁµÇ‰∫ÜÊôÇ„ÅÆÂá¶ÁêÜ
    tmux set-hook -g pane-exited \
        "run-shell 'idx=#{window_index}; \
        if [ \$idx -eq 0 ]; then \
            # window0„ÅØ2ÂàÜÂâ≤Á∂≠ÊåÅ
            panes=\$(tmux list-panes -t #{session_name}:0 2>/dev/null | wc -l); \
            [ \$panes -eq 1 ] && tmux split-window -h -t #{session_name}:0 -p 50; \
        elif [ \$idx -ne 0 ]; then \
            # window1‰ª•Èôç„ÅØ4ÂàÜÂâ≤Á∂≠ÊåÅÔºàÂùáÁ≠â„É¨„Ç§„Ç¢„Ç¶„Éà‰ΩøÁî®Ôºâ
            panes=\$(tmux list-panes -t #{session_name}:#{window_index} 2>/dev/null | wc -l); \
            if [ \$panes -lt 4 ] && [ \$panes -gt 0 ]; then \
                # ÁèæÂú®„ÅÆwindow„ÅÆ„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„ÇíÂèñÂæó
                cwd=\$(tmux display-message -t #{session_name}:#{window_index} -p \"#{pane_current_path}\"); \
                # ‰∏çË∂≥ÂàÜ„ÅÆ„Éö„Ç§„É≥„ÇíËøΩÂä†ÔºàÂêå„Åò„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„ÅßÔºâ
                while [ \$panes -lt 4 ]; do \
                    tmux split-window -h -t #{session_name}:#{window_index} -c \"\$cwd\"; \
                    panes=\$((panes + 1)); \
                done; \
                # ÂùáÁ≠â„Å™Ê∞¥Âπ≥„É¨„Ç§„Ç¢„Ç¶„Éà„ÇíÈÅ©Áî®ÔºàÂêÑ„Éö„Ç§„É≥25%Ôºâ
                tmux select-layout -t #{session_name}:#{window_index} even-horizontal; \
            fi \
        fi'"
    
    # Êñ∞Ë¶èwindow‰ΩúÊàêÊôÇ„ÅØ4ÂàÜÂâ≤ÔºàÁèæÂú®„ÅÆ„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„ÅßÔºâ
    tmux set-hook -t $SESSION_NAME after-new-window \
        "run-shell 'cwd=\$(tmux display-message -t #{session_name}:#{window_index} -p \"#{pane_current_path}\"); \
        tmux split-window -h -t #{session_name}:#{window_index} -c \"\$cwd\" -p 50; \
        tmux split-window -h -t #{session_name}:#{window_index}.0 -c \"\$cwd\" -p 50; \
        tmux split-window -h -t #{session_name}:#{window_index}.2 -c \"\$cwd\" -p 50'"
}

setup_hooks

# Window‰ΩúÊàêÔºàÁõ∏ÂØæ„Éë„ÇπË°®Á§∫Ôºâ
# ÁèæÂú®„ÅÆ„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„Åã„Çâ„ÅÆÁõ∏ÂØæ„Éë„Çπ
current_rel_path=${PWD#/home/nixos/bin/}
create_window 0 "$current_rel_path" "lazygit" "yazi"
create_window 1 "$current_rel_path"


# „Ç≠„Éº„Éê„Ç§„É≥„Éâ
tmux bind-key h select-pane -L
tmux bind-key j select-pane -D
tmux bind-key k select-pane -U
tmux bind-key l select-pane -R
tmux bind-key v copy-mode

# fzf„Åß„Éö„Ç§„É≥„Ç∏„É£„É≥„Éó (prefix + b)
tmux bind-key b display-popup -E -w 80% -h 80% \
    "tmux list-panes -a -F '#{session_name}:#{window_index}.#{pane_index} #{window_name} [#{pane_current_command}]' | \
    fzf --reverse --header='Jump to pane (ESC to cancel):' \
        --preview 'tmux capture-pane -p -t {1} 2>/dev/null || echo \"Pane content not available\"' \
        --preview-window=right:50% | \
    cut -d' ' -f1 | xargs -I {} tmux switch-client -t {} \\; select-pane -t {}"

# flake.nix„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™ÈÅ∏Êäû„Åó„Å¶Êñ∞Ë¶èwindow‰ΩúÊàê (prefix + c)
# nix shellÁµåÁî±„Åßfd + fzf„ÇíÂÆüË°å
tmux bind-key c display-popup -E -w 80% -h 80% \
    "nix shell nixpkgs#fd nixpkgs#fzf --command bash -c \"fd -H -t f 'flake.nix' '$HOME' | \
     sed 's|/flake.nix$||' | \
     fzf --reverse --header='Select flake directory:' | \
     xargs -I {} tmux new-window -c {}\""

# ÂÖÉ„ÅÆÂÆüË£ÖÔºà„Ç≥„É°„É≥„Éà„Ç¢„Ç¶„ÉàÔºâ
# tmux bind-key c display-popup -E -w 80% -h 80% \
#     "SCRIPT_DIR=\$(dirname \$(realpath ${BASH_SOURCE[0]:-\$0})); \
#     selected_dir=\$(\"\$SCRIPT_DIR/search-flakes-fast.sh\" 2>/dev/null); \
#     if [ -n \"\$selected_dir\" ]; then \
#         # „É¢„Éé„É¨„Éù„É´„Éº„Éà„Åã„Çâ„ÅÆÁõ∏ÂØæ„Éë„ÇπÂèñÂæó
#         rel_path=\${selected_dir#/home/nixos/bin/}; \
#         # „Éë„Çπ„ÅåÈï∑„ÅÑÂ†¥Âêà„ÅØÁúÅÁï•Ë®òÊ≥ï„Çí‰ΩøÁî®
#         if [ \$(echo \"\$rel_path\" | tr '/' '\\n' | wc -l) -gt 3 ]; then \
#             # ÊúÄÂàù„ÅÆ„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„Å®ÊúÄÂæå„ÅÆ2ÈöéÂ±§„Çí‰øùÊåÅ
#             first=\$(echo \"\$rel_path\" | cut -d'/' -f1); \
#             parent=\$(basename \$(dirname \"\$selected_dir\")); \
#             last=\$(basename \"\$selected_dir\"); \
#             window_name=\"\$first/.../\$parent/\$last\"; \
#         else \
#             window_name=\"\$rel_path\"; \
#         fi; \
#         tmux new-window -n \"\$window_name\" -c \"\$selected_dir\"; \
#     fi"

# „Ç≥„Éî„Éº„É¢„Éº„Éâ
tmux bind-key -T copy-mode-vi v send-keys -X begin-selection
tmux bind-key -T copy-mode-vi y send-keys -X copy-selection-and-cancel
tmux bind-key -T copy-mode-vi V send-keys -X select-line
tmux bind-key -T copy-mode-vi C-v send-keys -X rectangle-toggle



# ÊúÄÂàù„ÅÆ„Ç¶„Ç£„É≥„Éâ„Ç¶„ÇíÈÅ∏Êäû
tmux select-window -t "$SESSION_NAME:0"

# „Ç¢„Çø„ÉÉ„ÉÅ
tmux attach-session -t $SESSION_NAME

„ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÄÅ`/home/nixos/bin/src/develop/tmux/main.sh` „ÅØÂ≠òÂú®„Åó„Åæ„ÅôÔºÅ

**prefix + c** „ÅÆÂÆüË£Ö„ÇíË¶ã„Çã„Å®Ôºà178-183Ë°åÁõÆÔºâÔºö

```bash
tmux bind-key c display-popup -E -w 80% -h 80% \
```

content.text:
# orch
/orch

# Description
Split complex tasks into sequential steps, where each step can contain multiple parallel subtasks

# Execution

## Process

0. Á¶ÅÊ≠¢‰∫ãÈ†ÖÁ¢∫Ë™ç: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`

1. **Task Decomposition**
   - Use `/phase` command to decompose task into Baby Steps
   - Review generated phases and their dependencies

2. **Step-by-Step Execution**
   - Execute all subtasks within a step in parallel
   - Wait for all subtasks in current step to complete
   - Pass relevant results to next step
   - Request concise summaries (100-200 words) from each subtask

3. **Step Review and Adaptation**
   - After each step completion, review results
   - Validate if remaining steps are still appropriate
   - Adjust next steps based on discoveries

4. **Progressive Aggregation**
   - Synthesize results from completed step
   - Use synthesized results as context for next step
   - Build comprehensive understanding progressively

## Example Usage

When given "analyze test and fix issues":

**Step 1: Initial Analysis** (1 subtask)
- Analyze project structure to understand test setup

**Step 2: Quality Checks** (parallel subtasks)
- Run tests and capture results
- Run linting and type checking (see `/tested` command for comprehensive checks)
- Check current state of the project

**Step 3: Fix Issues** (parallel subtasks, using Step 2 results)
- Fix errors found in Step 2
- Update relevant documentation
*Review: If no errors found in Step 2, skip fixes and proceed*

**Step 4: Final Validation** (parallel subtasks)
- Re-run tests to ensure fixes work
- Verify all issues resolved
*Review: If Step 3 had no fixes, simplify validation*

## Key Benefits

- **Sequential Logic**: Steps execute in order, allowing later steps to use earlier results
- **Parallel Efficiency**: Within each step, independent tasks run simultaneously
- **Memory Optimization**: Each subtask gets minimal context, preventing overflow
- **Progressive Understanding**: Build knowledge incrementally across steps
- **Clear Dependencies**: Explicit flow from analysis ‚Üí execution ‚Üí validation

## Implementation Notes

- Always start with a single analysis task to understand the full scope
- Group related parallel tasks within the same step
- Pass only essential findings between steps (summaries, not full output)
- Use TodoWrite to track both steps and subtasks for visibility
- After each step, explicitly reconsider the plan:
  - Are the next steps still relevant?
  - Did we discover something that requires new tasks?
  - Can we skip or simplify upcoming steps?
  - Should we add new validation steps?
- For comprehensive testing and linting, use the `/tested` command

## Adaptive Planning Example

```
Initial Plan: Step 1 ‚Üí Step 2 ‚Üí Step 3 ‚Üí Step 4

After Step 2: "No errors found in tests or linting"
Adapted Plan: Step 1 ‚Üí Step 2 ‚Üí Skip Step 3 ‚Üí Simplified Step 4

After Step 2: "Found critical architectural issue"
Adapted Plan: Step 1 ‚Üí Step 2 ‚Üí New Step 2.5 (analyze architecture) ‚Üí Modified Step 3
```

## Integration with Other Commands

- `/phase`: **ÂøÖÈ†à** - „Çø„Çπ„ÇØ„ÇíBaby Steps„Å´ÂàÜËß£ÔºàÂÆüË°åÂâç„Å´ÂøÖ„Åö‰ΩøÁî®Ôºâ
- `/tested`: For comprehensive test and lint checking
- `/org`: For simple parallel task execution without dependencies
- `/discuss`: For architectural discussions when issues are found

#!/usr/bin/env bash
# bash_histories.sh - Simple bash history search without flake evaluation
# Designed to be called with: nix shell nixpkgs#fzf --command bash bash_histories.sh

# Exit if no bash history
if [ ! -f ~/.bash_history ]; then
    echo "No bash history file found" >&2
    exit 1
fi

# Search bash history with fzf
tac ~/.bash_history | 
awk '!seen[$0]++' | 
fzf --height ${FZF_TMUX_HEIGHT:-40%} $FZF_DEFAULT_OPTS -n2..,.. --tiebreak=index --bind=ctrl-r:toggle-sort $FZF_CTRL_R_OPTS --query="$READLINE_LINE" +m

# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. Á¶ÅÊ≠¢‰∫ãÈ†ÖÁ¢∫Ë™ç: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl ‚Üí Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py ‚Üí Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log ‚Üí Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

export TERM="xterm-256color"
export COLORTERM="truecolor"
eval "$(dircolors -b)"
# If not running interactively, don't do anything
case $- in
    *i*) ;;
      *) return;;
esac
# don't put duplicate lines or lines starting with space in the history.
# See bash(1) for more options
HISTCONTROL=ignoreboth
# append to the history file, don't overwrite it
shopt -s histappend
# for setting history length see HISTSIZE and HISTFILESIZE in bash(1)
# HISTSIZE=1000
HISTFILESIZE=2000
# check the window size after each command and, if necessary,
# update the values of LINES and COLUMNS.
shopt -s checkwinsize
# make less more friendly for non-text input files, see lesspipe(1)
[ -x /usr/bin/lesspipe ] && eval "$(SHELL=/bin/sh lesspipe)"
# set variable identifying the chroot you work in (used in the prompt below)
if [ -z "${debian_chroot:-}" ] && [ -r /etc/debian_chroot ]; then
    debian_chroot=$(cat /etc/debian_chroot)
fi
# set a fancy prompt (non-color, unless we know we "want" color)
case "$TERM" in
    xterm-color|*-256color) color_prompt=yes;;
esac
if [ -n "$force_color_prompt" ]; then
    if [ -x /usr/bin/tput ] && tput setaf 1 >&/dev/null; then
        # We have color support; assume it's compliant with Ecma-48
        # (ISO/IEC-6429). (Lack of such support is extremely rare, and such
        # a case would tend to support setf rather than setaf.)
        color_prompt=yes
    else
        color_prompt=
    fi
fi
# enable color support of ls and also add handy aliases
if [ -x /usr/bin/dircolors ]; then
    test -r ~/.dircolors && eval "$(dircolors -b ~/.dircolors)" || eval "$(dircolors -b)"
    alias ls='ls --color=auto'
    #alias dir='dir --color=auto'
    #alias vdir='vdir --color=auto'
    alias grep='grep --color=auto'
    alias fgrep='fgrep --color=auto'
    alias egrep='egrep --color=auto'
fi
# some more ls aliases
alias ll='ls -alF'
alias la='ls -A'
alias l='ls -CF'
# Add an "alert" alias for long running commands.  Use like so:
#   sleep 10; alert
alias alert='notify-send --urgency=low -i "$([ $? = 0 ] && echo terminal || echo error)" "$(history|tail -n1|sed -e '\''s/^\s*[0-9]\+\s*//;s/[;&|]\s*alert$//'\'')"'
# Alias definitions.
# You may want to put all your additions into a separate file like
# ~/.bash_aliases, instead of adding them here directly.
# See /usr/share/doc/bash-doc/examples in the bash-doc package.
# TODO: ËõªÔΩ•ÁπùËºî„ÅÉÁπßÔΩ§ÁπùÔΩ´Á∏∫ÔΩ∏ÈÅòÔΩªÈô¶„Éª$HOME/.config/shell/bash_aliases Á∏∫ÔΩ´ÈÅòÔΩªËúçËºîÔº†Á∏∫ÔΩ¶Á∏≤‚àöÔºÖÁ∏∫ÔΩÆÁπùËºî„ÅÉÁπßÔΩ§ÁπùÔΩ´Á∏∫‰πùÔΩâÁ∏∫ÔΩØËúë‰ºÅÂãÅ
if [ -f ~/.bash_aliases ]; then
    . ~/.config/shell/bash_aliases
fi
# enable programmable completion features (you don't need to enable
# this, if it's already enabled in /etc/bash.bashrc and /etc/profile
# sources /etc/bash.bashrc).
if ! shopt -oq posix; then
  if [ -f /usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion ]; then
    . /usr/share/bash-completion/bash_completion
  elif [ -f /etc/bash_completion ]; then
    . /etc/bash_completion
  fi
fi
# eval "$(starship init bash)"
# Source traditional shell scripts
for file in $HOME/.config/shell/*.sh; do
    if [ "$(basename "$file")" != "main.sh" ]; then
        source "$file"
        # echo "sourced $file"
    fi
done

# Bash history search
bind -x '"\C-r": READLINE_LINE=$(nix shell $HOME/bin/src/poc/develop/search/bash_histories -c search-bash-histories); READLINE_POINT=${#READLINE_LINE}'
# export GO111MODULE=on
# export GOPATH=
export EDITOR=hx

# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. Á¶ÅÊ≠¢‰∫ãÈ†ÖÁ¢∫Ë™ç: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl ‚Üí Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py ‚Üí Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log ‚Üí Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

ARGUMENTS: 

‰æãÂ§ñÁöÑ„Å´
I'll commit the main.sh file that I just edited, even though it's outside the current directory (as per the exceptional permission given).
